trans-unit.source: Network encryption and authentication with SSL/TLS

seg-source.mrk: Network encryption and authentication with SSL/TLS

target.mrk: Network encryption and authentication with SSL/TLS

trans-unit.source: By default, all <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> network traffic is unencrypted, with the exception of user names and user passwords, which may be encrypted separately.

seg-source.mrk: By default, all <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> network traffic is unencrypted, with the exception of user names and user passwords, which may be encrypted separately.

target.mrk: By default, all <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> network traffic is unencrypted, with the exception of user names and user passwords, which may be encrypted separately.

seg-source.mrk: Network Server

target.mrk: Network Server

seg-source.mrk: SSL

target.mrk: SSL

seg-source.mrk: Network Server

target.mrk: Network Server

seg-source.mrk: TLS

target.mrk: TLS

seg-source.mrk: SSL

target.mrk: SSL

seg-source.mrk: TLS

target.mrk: TLS

seg-source.mrk: See <xref href="cadminappsclientsecurity.dita#cadminappsclientsecurity"></xref> for more information.

target.mrk: See <xref href="cadminappsclientsecurity.dita#cadminappsclientsecurity"></xref> for more information.

trans-unit.source: There is also no network layer access control mechanism. For deployment scenarios where these are possible security issues, the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server supports network security with Secure Socket Layer/Transport Layer Security (SSL/TLS).

seg-source.mrk: There is also no network layer access control mechanism.

For deployment scenarios where these are possible security issues, the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server supports network security with Secure Socket Layer/Transport Layer Security (SSL/TLS).

target.mrk: There is also no network layer access control mechanism.

For deployment scenarios where these are possible security issues, the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server supports network security with Secure Socket Layer/Transport Layer Security (SSL/TLS).

trans-unit.source: With SSL/TLS, the client/server communication protocol is encrypted, and both the client and the server may, independently of each other, require certificate-based authentication of the other part.

seg-source.mrk: With SSL/TLS, the client/server communication protocol is encrypted, and both the client and the server may, independently of each other, require certificate-based authentication of the other part.

target.mrk: With SSL/TLS, the client/server communication protocol is encrypted, and both the client and the server may, independently of each other, require certificate-based authentication of the other part.

trans-unit.source: It is assumed that the reader is somewhat familiar with SSL, key pairs, and certificates. This documentation is also based on the Java Development Kit (JDK) and its <codeph>keytool</codeph> application.

seg-source.mrk: It is assumed that the reader is somewhat familiar with SSL, key pairs, and certificates.
This documentation is also based on the Java Development Kit (JDK) and its <codeph>keytool</codeph> application.

target.mrk: It is assumed that the reader is somewhat familiar with SSL, key pairs, and certificates.
This documentation is also based on the Java Development Kit (JDK) and its <codeph>keytool</codeph> application.

trans-unit.source: For the remainder of this section, the term SSL is used for SSL/TLS, and the term peer is used for the other part of the communication (the server's peer is the client and vice versa).

seg-source.mrk: For the remainder of this section, the term SSL is used for SSL/TLS, and the term peer is used for the other part of the communication (the server's peer is the client and vice versa).

target.mrk: For the remainder of this section, the term SSL is used for SSL/TLS, and the term peer is used for the other part of the communication (the server's peer is the client and vice versa).

trans-unit.source: SSL for <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> (both for client and for server) operates in three possible modes:

seg-source.mrk: SSL for <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> (both for client and for server) operates in three possible modes:

target.mrk: SSL for <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> (both for client and for server) operates in three possible modes:

seg-source.mrk: off

target.mrk: off

seg-source.mrk: The default, no SSL encryption

target.mrk: The default, no SSL encryption

seg-source.mrk: basic

target.mrk: basic

seg-source.mrk: SSL encryption, no peer authentication

target.mrk: SSL encryption, no peer authentication

seg-source.mrk: peerAuthentication

target.mrk: peerAuthentication

seg-source.mrk: SSL encryption and peer authentication

target.mrk: SSL encryption and peer authentication

trans-unit.source: Peer authentication may be set on the server, on the client, or on both. Peer authentication means that the other side of the SSL connection is authenticated based on a trusted certificate installed locally.

seg-source.mrk: Peer authentication may be set on the server, on the client, or on both.
Peer authentication means that the other side of the SSL connection is authenticated based on a trusted certificate installed locally.

target.mrk: Peer authentication may be set on the server, on the client, or on both.
Peer authentication means that the other side of the SSL connection is authenticated based on a trusted certificate installed locally.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, a Certification Authority (CA) certificate may be installed locally and the peer has a certificate signed by that authority. How to achieve this is not described in this document. Consult your Java environment documentation for details on this.

seg-source.mrk: Alternatively, a Certification Authority (CA) certificate may be installed locally and the peer has a certificate signed by that authority.
How to achieve this is not described in this document.
Consult your Java environment documentation for details on this.

target.mrk: Alternatively, a Certification Authority (CA) certificate may be installed locally and the peer has a certificate signed by that authority.
How to achieve this is not described in this document.
Consult your Java environment documentation for details on this.

trans-unit.source: If a plaintext client tries to communicate with an SSL server, or if an SSL client tries to communicate with a plaintext server, the plaintext side of the communication will see the SSL communication as noise and report protocol errors.

seg-source.mrk: If a plaintext client tries to communicate with an SSL server, or if an SSL client tries to communicate with a plaintext server, the plaintext side of the communication will see the SSL communication as noise and report protocol errors.

target.mrk: If a plaintext client tries to communicate with an SSL server, or if an SSL client tries to communicate with a plaintext server, the plaintext side of the communication will see the SSL communication as noise and report protocol errors.
